text:
[Philip Defranco] It is
Friday March twenty-seventh
twenty-twenty my name is Philip Defranco.
Welcome back to the Philip Defranco show

and for today's Friday
show I have a little
something different and special for you.
One of the most trusted people,

one the most trusted
experts in this coronavirus

pandemic is a guy by the
name of Dr. Anthony Fauci.
He's an immunilogist serves as director

of the National Insitute of
Allergy and Infectious Diseases

and is a member of the
coronavirus task force.

And fantastically I was able
to get ahold of Dr. Fauci

for fifteen minutes to
ask some frequently asked

questions from you guys
as well there's just
been some things I've been wondering as
I've watched the press conferences.

And just really quick
before we jump into that
I wanted to thank in general our sponsors
but also for this video specifically
thank you to Vessi Footwear.
Who have recently committed to donating
over thirty thousand medical masks to
organizations that need the most in both
the United States and Canada.

So your Vessi purchases
will actually support

our healthcare workers in
the fight against COVID-19.
Which I'll talk about more later but,
with that said here is Dr. Fauci.

Dr. Fauci thank you so
much for making the time.
I'm gonna just gonna kinda jump into it.

We have some prepared
questions some questions
from our audience as well.
Yesterday you said that we needa really
be prepared for another cycle right?

Why do you think we're
currently you're currently
seeing this as potentially seasonal?
- [Dr. Fauci] Well I mean I don't want
seasonal to be thinking that well its okay

because its just gonna
be a plain old seasonal.

When I said another cycle,
given the robust nature

of the transmissability
and the fact that it is

global throughout the world
and we're seeing cases now
in the southern hemisphere.
Southern Africa in the southern hemisphere
which are entering in their winter,
It is concievable and maybe likely that
they're gonna have a big surge through
what is their winter and our summer.

Once you have circulating
virus in the world,

through our summer and
as we get into the fall,
invariably it would come back in the fall.

So that's the reason
even though we handle it

which we will, well as we get
into the warmer months now.
I feel we need to be absolutely prepared

for another surge as we get
into next fall and winter.
- [Philip Defranco] Okay so that's the
next fall next winter. Now would this be

would we expect this to
be the same virus that's

hitting everyone now? So
lets say obviously there's
no magic wand that's been a you know

a constant thing said, if
a vaccine was developed

do we believe it would
be something that would
affect the next waves?

- [Dr. Fauci] Yeah I do in
vaccinology and in medicine

you never know for sure
but there is no indication

as we do molecular analysis
of the virus as it evolves
that this is mutating to the point of
having any functional difference.
If you compare viruses in China, in Italy,

in the rest of Europe,
in the United States
that's one of the reasons why

you know you may have heard
we started a vaccine trial
about a week and half two weeks ago.

Its the fastest we've
ever gone from discovering
a virus to getting it to the trial.

Even with that speed,
it would take at least
a year before we know if this works.

So hopefully if we can able
to show an efficacy signal,

that we may be able to not
only have a vaccine late

in next season, but also a
number of drugs that we're
testing on randomized control trials.
So its gonna be a different ball game

if we get back next season.
Its not gonna be hit
the way we're hit now because
we will be much better prepared.

- [Philip Defranco] Right
now actually kind of on

preparation yesterday
you talked about in China

they're seeing imported
cases that we need to keep

that in mind. What would
your recommended strategy
be for the United States there?

- [Dr. Fauci] Well, in
the United States if we
and that's more than if its when because
we will get it under control.
When we get this under control, if there's

a lot of activity in the
rest of the world which,
there likely will be, I would be reluctant

to just very liberally release
the travel restrictions
of people coming into the country because
you don't want all of your hard work to

suppress the outbreak
only to have it receded.

I was on a telephone call
just yesterday morning

with the WHO who has like
literally fifty people
on the phone from different countries and

our Chinese colleagues
were there warning us

saying we've finally got
our epidemic under control

but we're starting to see
receding now from other
countries that are traveling into China.
So we've really gotta be careful,
we've really gotta be careful.

- [Philip Defranco] Now
when you're saying that

we needa be careful for
you is it more of an

international issue where
I know that yesterday

there was a conversation
of people leaving New York

which is if we wanna
use the word hot spot,

possibly going to Florida
and several other states,
do we see this also as a potential
domestic issue more sort term?

- [Dr Fauci] You know short
term domestic its true.
I mean the recommendation that was made
and I was in the task force room
when the recommendation was discussed,

was that about a million
people were leaving New York.

Because that New York
was suffering so badly.

They were going to
Florida. They were going

out on Long Island, to the
Hamptons and places where
people who can afford that go and
they were bringing the infection.
And for that reason it was said that

if you were in New York
within the last fourteen days,
when you reach your destination,

you have got to essentially
sequester yourself in place
for a total of fourteen days.

And that's what the
recommendation is right now

to prevent the hot spot
of New York being spread

to the hot spot of other
parts of the country.

- [Philip Defranco] A few
questions from our audience

just so you know the
different tone change.(laughs)
This one from Morgan,

"I'm in the high-risk
category and I'm already

hearing about hospitals
lacking supplies and beds

for those who need treatment.
In the event I get sick

and do have access to care,
is there anything I can do
for myself at home that would increase
my change of making it through?"

- [Dr Fauci] Yeah well,
the general rule is
if you get sick get a fever and
think you might have coronavirus disease,

you wanna go home. Then you
wanna contact a physician

and get instructions as
to what you should do.
Let them evaluate you over the phone.
Perhaps say we're gonna get you tested.

He may not say that he
may say if you're stable

you're doing well, stay
home just ride it out.

Or they may get you
tested or if it looks like

you're not doing well,
definitely get you to a facility

where you can be taken
care of. But the first move

is not to walk into an
emergency room because
that's how you infect other people.
- [Philip Defranco] "Should we be avoiding
food delivery service right now? Obviously

more people are staying home
even with no contact options.

Someone made the food.
Someone packaged it."
- [Dr Fauci] The answer is no with care.
So when you get anything delivered,

could be food, somebody
touching a doorknob,
wash your hands literally in an
obsessive and compulsive way.
Just wash your hands as much as your can

you know rub down doorknobs
with clorox or alcohol.

But I like the idea about
pickup food or home delivery
because its takes you out of
the environment of a restaurant.

It would be worse to be
in a crowded restaurant

than to have a single person
who you ask to wash their hands

deliver a package to you
or you go to a restaurant

and pick it up. I did that
myself last night (laughs)

I mean one of my favorite
restaurants in my neighborhood

in Washington D.C. I just am
very sorry I don't go to it
because I'm doing social distancing.

So I ordered what I like,
went, put my credit card down,

wiped it off with wipe,
put it in my pocket and

took the bag and went
home. It worked perfectly.

- [Philip Defranco] Do
we have a clear picture
as far as the far as the full extent of
possible damage COVID-19 can do to lungs?

I know there's been a big
focus on the fatality rate,

the differences there but what
about people that get sick?

Do you recover? Do we have an
idea about the lung damage?

- [Dr. Fauci] Good question.
I mean as you know,

the data mostly from
China and other places,

about eighty plus percent of
the people that get infected

spontaniously recover without
any medical intervention.

About fifteen percent do badly
in the sense of requiring

sometimes intensive
hospital care. Among those,

most of them are individuals
who are either elderly
or have an underlying condition.
Heart disease, lung disease, diabtes, etc.

What we have not yet
done, someone is doing it
but the data aren't out yet, is that

when someone recovers or
on a respirator they have

pulmonary infiltrates, they
get out of the hospital
and they're doing well is to follow up

what the pulmonary function
is, have they knocked

out a considerable amount
of pulmonary function?

What's the ejection
fraction of their heart?

Which is a parameter
of the function of your

of the ability of your
heart to pump blood around.
We don't know that yet but we're gonna get

that information cus
somebody's collecting it.

- [Philip Defranco] I believe
you've answered this before
but it was one of the most requested,

"Are you able to contract
the virus more than once?

And even after we believe
that you're recovered,

how long would you remain
a potential carrier?

- [Dr Fauci] Okay so the
answer to the first question.

Is that if this virus acts
like every other virus

we know which we have no
reason to believe it will not,
that once you are infected and you

clear the infection
successfully and you're well,
you will be protected against subsequent
exposure to the same virus.
We haven't definitively proven that
by any re-challenging of people.
But it just make virilogical sense since

that's what we we see with
virtually any other virus.
How long you're infected depends on
how long you're shedding virus.

I mean I might get infected
when I get sick and get better
and feel well but still be shedding virus

and that's the reason why
before you can be certain,

you should have two negative
swabs twenty-four hours apart
to know that you're okay to go.

- [Philip Defranco]
And regarding you know,
people having and people not having it
there's been more and more talk over
the past forty-eight hours of the

I believe its called the
convalecent serum treatment

that the FDA is expedited.
Do you know can you kind of

expand on how and why
or even what that is?
- [Dr. Fauci] Okay so if I get infected

and I clear the virus my
body clears the virus by
making a protein called an antibody.

That antibody is protected
against my getting infected again
and its also the mechanism that
suppressed the virus in my body.

So what we do is that we
withdraw from a person

who has recovered their serum
is called convalecent serum.

And we either infuse it into
someone else to protect them

or to treat them or we
concentrate the specific component
of that serum called immunoglobulin

and we give it to a
person as immunoglobulin.

The other way is a much
more sophisticated way

where you take some of
the cells from a person

that's making the
antibody, you clone it and

you produce covious
amounts of this antibody

and passively infuse it that's
called monoclonal antibodies.

- [Philip Defranco] Are there
any questions that Dr. Fauci
wishes were being asked more in general?
- [Dr. Fauci] I mean I think its less
of a question to realize

to get people to know that
it is really effective

when you listen to the guidelines
of physical separation.

You know the fifteen day
guidelines that came out

of the White House that
the President put out.
Namely no more than ten people in a crowd,
Tele-work when you can, stay out of bars,

stay out of restaurants I
mean even though you love

sporting events and places
just stay out of them.
Try to physically separate yourself.

Wash your hands very very
frequently and carefully.
And if you are or have the responsibility
for an elderly person or someone

with an underlying condition,
get them out of society.

Put them in a place where they
can comfortably self isolate.

You don't wanna socially
isolate them you know
you wanna talk to them you wanna you know

convey things by telephone
by YouTube or whatever.

But physically separate
yourself from them.

- [Philip Defranco]
Definitely and Dr. Fauci

kind of just a last question
because we only see you

for that kind of sixty
minutes to two hours a day,

what does a day for you
look like when its not
you talking to me and I guess Seth Curry
and other people today? (laughs)

- [Dr Fauci] Well you know
its very intense I mean

the last couple of months I've
been getting about four hour
sleep a night maybe sometimes less.

You know you get up in
the morning, five o'clock
you do the morning shows you know

the the radio and TV
shows. I come into the NIH

because I do have a day
job besides this (laughs)

and you know work with my team
about developing a vaccine
you know developing drugs doing
the kinds of things we need to do.

Then I go down to the
White House and I spend

the rest of the afternoon
at the White house

We have a task force meeting
lasts about an hour and a half.
We do that with the Vice President.

When we finish that everyday
we go in to the President
we sit down in the Oval Office
with him for a good half hour. Talk about

what we need to do what're
the kinds of things we do.
Then we have the daily press conference
which goes into the early evening.
Then I go home do more media
to get people to be aware of it.

Then I spend the next few
hours reading up on things

so that I can keep up
what's going on not only

in the United States but
the rest of the world.

So its kind of a intense day
which turns into intense weeks.

- [Philip Defranco] Right
well thank you so much

for your time I know
that you're slammed today
I really really appreciate this.

- [Dr. Fauci] My pleasure
always good to be
with you take care.
- [Philip Defranco] Take care.
And that was our chat slash interview

obviously Dr. Fauci very
busy I was so thankful

that he even had fifteen
minutes to give us.

And hey if you like the video,
it gave you some insight

let us know hit the like
button maybe share it

with someone else that
doesn't know everything
that they should probably know.

And finally I wanted to give
another big thank you to
Vessi Footwear for sponsoring this video.

Our friends at Vessi
have already donated over

one-thousand pairs of
their sneakers to Canadian
healthcare professionals fighting
on the front lines of COVID-19.

Today they're announcing
an exciting new initiative
to donate the profits of every sale to

provide protective gear
to resource constrained

healthcare organizations in
both the U.S. and Canada.
Already committing to donating over
thirty-thousand medical masks.

And that's not all for
a limited time Vessi

is introducing choose
what you pay model and
we're gonna drive even larger donations
of personal protective equipment for
our brave healthcare professionals.
Also I kind of got ahead of myself

if you don't know Vessi's
are incredibly comfortable
and one-hundred percent water proof
and weather proof shoes making them
the perfect every day shoe.
My favorites are definitely the
men's every day in midnight black.

So don't wait head on over
to Vessi Footwear dot com
slash DeFranco today and choose
what you pay for a limited time.
Your contributions towards Vessi's efforts

to protect our healthcare
heroes in these uncertain times.

And really I love when you see
brands stepping up like this.

But with that said thank
you for watching this video

and also of course as always
my name is Philip DeFranco
you've just been filled in I love yo faces
and I'll see you next time.
